author: Juan Sebastian Echeverry
title: Prsona: Dapp for political personas
description: Political parties represent the people without really knowing much about the people. How can parties collect and use info about the people?

assessments.note: this idea fits in the challenges, and it can maybe used later in voltaire for the cardano gouvernance

This could be an interesting idea, however it seems to mainly be an idea for a piece of software for one specific political party in the Netherlands. Does project Catalyst want to fund this? How are you making it widely available? Given it is initially being developed for a party in the Netherlands, what language is its UX in?

The potential of this idea is huge however there are unknown risks in adaptation. Security of the digital persona, acceptance by the people to put their preferences in open block chain and various regulatory compliance. It is a bold experiment and there are strong reasons to try it.

The way the political system is being described as functioning in the Netherlands, this proposal has the potential to produce a dApp that many people will be enticed to use, thus attracting more people to the Cardano ecosystem.

Great idea in terms of political analysis, but there's a huge issue. If this project receives Catalyst funding, then Project Catalyst would indirectly fund a political party and that means conflict of interest. Project Catalyst should remain neutral on political stances. So the proposal is a good idea if it were to exclude any possibility of funding a political party and just offer the service to anyone interested. I would also have sincere concerns about sharing my full political spectrum and making that public for anyone to see.

The proposal aims to onboard people onto the cardano blockchain, however the problem statement is a problem for the political parties and not the people themselves, so it's unclear how the people will benefit from being surveilled and have their info minted into the block chain without Self Sovereignty, which was never mentioned in the proposal. Self sovereignty is essential in order to be aligned with decentralization, otherwise central powers will exert power over individuals. Which would be the case here.

This is an interesting proposal of a blockchain based political party subscription service that allows a political party to gather data about its supporters and their wishes. The initial pilot is in Netherlands which seems very Cardano-friendly so I could see some success there, even though the onboarding numbers would be small at first. If the idea caught on on a larger scale, it could have a tremendous onboarding and legitimizing effect for Cardano.

It is not clear the proposers have the technical ability to deliver this project. A question for the governance design. Have you thought about how to get people to compromise? Direct voting can lead to large issues where minorities are not protected and people vote for incompatible things (high services and low taxation for insatnce).

The proposer has wide experience in handling large projects and is associated with a political party. The proposer is also planning to hire independent firms for implementation. There is a very goof chance that the proposal will be implemented.

The proposal's budget is only for the 1st phase out of 3, so only for USD16500 out of a total budget of USD76500, the rest being planned for future funds. The proposer is not a developer, he plans of hiring a professional team for the development side. Since the developers are not invested in this project, they would only be work for hire, is there not a big risk of the project not getting funded in a future round and losing all the investments done thus far? A possible solution would be to split the proposal in two phases, each one having a larger budget, but reducing the chances of not being funded and of not having some MVP at the end of the first phase.

The proposer's experience is composed out of a fuction as a marketing professional and member of a political party.  
I only see it as a great service for militant members of a political party, but not for the general public as they tend to keep their voting preferences private. So there would be a need to provide an option to keep track of this data anonymously. It would be necessary to create different frameworks per nation as not every nation makes use of the same political system.

The proposer has limited experience with block chain tech and what issues it can solve. this is apparent by the misapplication in this proposal where the problem identified was not one of trust in exchange. The proposal aims to centralize data and make it more available to political parties which makes them more powerful, the antithesis of public, permission less blockchains. The proposer didn't mention the W3 DID standard which means there is a risk of interoperability. In addition, the lack of blockchain experience means the confidence in the budget is extremely weak, since blockchain dev work is extremely expensive. The project didn't identify how the data would be stored either.

The team does not appear to have much blockchain experience. The current proposal is not for development, but developing the framework, website, branding, and legal consulting. I think the team will need to bring on some additional partners to understand the technical aspects of the Dapp, but meeting their stated goals appears feasible.

It is not clear that the technical side of this project has been planned and thus feasibility is an issue. Given it is being developed for a specific political party in one country, does it address the challenge of providing the most value for end users in 2021? More detail on who this would be provided to political parties (or any other groups requiring governance) around the world would be useful.

The complete process is being implemented in three stages and the current fund is for the first stage which also includes evolving detailed plan. Therefore it can be seen that an unforseen risk can emerge during this evolution stage. There are clear stages and metrics for evaluating the progress of the proposal.

The project per total has clear verifiable metrics, yet the proposal is only for the first phase of the entire project, which has 3 in total. For this first phase, there is not enough information that would help the community assess it, leading to the possibility of the project not being finished.

The data presented in the proposal suffices in terms of metrics, budget breakdown and roadmap. What is lacking, though, is a risk assessment that is paired with making political preferences public, especially in nations where there is political instability.

The proposal did identify a scope, timeline, and budget which was broken down. this could be used to audit the success of the proposal. However, it there is little to show for a plan for audit of the code.

the allocation of the 16.5K in funding for the first round is not detailed, but clear and realistic goals are laid out for this phase.  While not particularly easy to audit, we can expect a website explaining the nature of the project. I expect the most relevant and auditable data will be presented in future catalysts rounds where we will hopefully see a detailed technical roadmap resulting from the research done in this phase.

solution: We will build a poll dapp that gathers the political preferences and wishes of people. Parties can use the data to represent people better.
